results.title: A Place to belong
results.creator_credit: Brian McKenzie, Daniel Scharf and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The old inner city suburb of Port Melbourne has been the traditional home for generations of working people whose community is bound by ties of class, church, sport and family. But the cohesion of the neighbourhood is threatened by the pressures of modernisation and an influx of young professionals. Filmmaker, Brian McKenzie, lets the people of “Port” tell their own stories in this affectionate portrait of a community who have always felt they “belonged” but increasingly find their children are moving away to other suburbs in the struggle for affordable housing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian McKenzie, Daniel Scharf and Film Australia

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Irving Lerner and Documentary Film Productions
results.brief_description: Philadelphia was originally built as a city of fine homes and buildings, but just as the city and its industries grew, so did the areas of dilapidated housing. Life was a struggle for existence for those unfortunates in the abysmal slums. However with moves under way for urban renewal, new housing will arise where the ruins were. The life a mother leads with her young son and daughter in the slums with their hope for something better in the future is the story line.

results.title: Will you join?
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Union Representative”.
A new man starts work in a warehouse and is immediately approached by the union representative and told that it is in his best interests to join the Union. This approach offends the new man and he decides to seek another job. This film is an examination of the union delegate’s role and his manner in recruiting members.

results.title: Changes in the office
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Union Representative”.
The female union representative approaches a company manager to find out whether or not automated office equipment is to be installed which will cause fifty percent of the staff to be made redundant. Focuses on the manner in which the union delegate approaches the manager and how well she fulfils her role in representing the staff. Suitable for tertiary level.

results.title: A Place of dreams: National Air and Space Museum
results.creator_credit: Peter S Vogt and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: An examination of the Smithsonian Institute, home of America’s early planes. Shows through the use of early film and still photographs, the Wright Brothers’ early failures and successes; looks at the restoration of old planes at the museum; and presents a history of the development of flight in the United States. Presented by Cliff Robertson. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Place to work
results.creator_credit: M.J. Clark, W. J. Allen and J. Arthur Rank Organisation
results.brief_description: Part of the “Patterns of living” series. Looks at Luxembourg’s iron and steel industry, Danish ship-building, Scottish fish processing, Swiss watch making and British car assembly to demonstrate the range and complexity of factors affecting the location of modern manufacturing industries. Considers transport costs, industrial inertia, decline and regeneration of industry. Useful as a resource for studies relating to manufacturing locations. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: A Personal matter
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Murray, Australian Council for Union Training and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Union Representative”.
A migrant worker in a factory needs time off to take his sick wife to hospital, but the union representative does not see this as a sufficiently important matter for him to deal with. Raises the question of prejudices and principles of justice and fair play in relation to the union’s responsibility to the individual worker.

results.title: A Place for everything
results.creator_credit: Eric M Nilsson, National Film Board of Canada and Svenska filminstitutet
results.brief_description: Eric Nilsson examines the attitudes of Swedish young people, and others critical of the well-ordered society. The established institutions are considered to be inflexible, and lacking in dynamism. A plea is made for independence, imagination, and more discussion of existing conditions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eric M Nilsson, National Film Board of Canada and Svenska filminstitutet

results.title: A Place to live: building in Maine
results.creator_credit: Fred James and Lumen Bel Productions
results.brief_description: This film shows how Pat and Patsy Hennim of Maine, U.S., adapt different building theories to build their own home in the woods, minimising on costs and maximising on living conditions. In turn they teach their ideas to a group of students.
